title: This Hub is all abuzz with activity—GitHub, that is
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: DSX and GitHub integration means a lot more collaboration. Combine code, data, and visualizations and then track changes through all the iterations. It all starts with the IBM Data Science Experience Integrations tab, where you combine your GitHub account with DSX. So start buzzing!

title: JSON, Mom called and said to stop being so difficult!
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: You called, we listened. We made it much easier to load JSON data from Object Storage. Now from inside a notebook you can click a JSON file and get options for loading it into Python and R notebooks. Also, you know how Mom always wants you to be social and share things? Well, we made that possible from within a notebook. DSX notebooks are shareable to LinkedIn and Twitter. As always, you can limit what you share. Thanks, Mom.

title: Share your Jupyter notebooks
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Feel like sharing? We’ve got an option for every comfort level. If your notebook is wide-eyed and ready for the world, you can share all notebook content with stakeholders or other data scientists. If it’s still a bit bashful, share only the output, or share a version that hides sensitive information like access credentials.

title: Fuel your experience with data
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Add data as you work: simply drag a file into a project or notebook, and it’s added to your object storage. Don’t be afraid to fill up—remember, you get 5 GB for free!

title: New product documentation
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Even the best explorers like to have a map. Our product documentation is here to help you find your way!

title: Version control for notebooks
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Be daring with your data –we’ve got you covered. You can now save versions of your notebooks, view the change history, and even restore previous versions.

title: Real-time comments in notebooks
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Say what you need to say. Collaboration is easier than ever with the new comments section in Jupyter notebooks.

title: Project tabs to classify your assets
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Take the high-level view, skim the surface, or dive deep! With project tabs, you can quickly review your project or get the gritty details on notebooks, assets, and collaborators.

title: Admit it. You know you have your favorites!
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Why not bookmark them so you your find your favorite community cards even faster? Add your favorite bookmarks to projects to share them with your colleagues.

title: Like their real-world namesakes, using Anaconda and Python 3.5 on Jupyter Notebooks is huge!
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Now you can use Anaconda distribution with hundreds of Open Source packages already pre-installed.

title: Now with extra sparkle!
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Just in time for the holidays, Spark 2.0 is available! Some are calling it the best Spark ever, with all the stability, all the new APIs, at faster speeds, and better throughput.

title: DataFrames in a hurry for your Jupyter notebooks
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: Finding the path to loading data into your Jupyter notebook a little cloudy? Cut through the haze and get right to your analysis by creating DataFrames for pandas, Spark SQL and RDD, and R ... in a single click.

title: Creative visualizations, fast and easy with Brunel
author: Armand Ruiz Gabernet
message: We all know how a picture often tells a story best, especially with data. Now that we support Brunel interactive visualizations in our Jupyter notebooks for Scala and Python, you can squeeze Brunel's flexibility and variety onto your palette and focus on setting your imagination free instead of learning a complex tool.
